snippet: There appeared to be consensus on the court that prosecutors in 1987 crossed a constitutional line in a capital case against a black man accused of killing a white woman.
abstract: Supreme Court justices are considering whether jurors were excluded based on race from 1987 capital murder trial of Timothy T Foster, black man accused of killing Queen Madge White, who was white; Supreme Court has previously ruled that race discrimination in jury selection is  unconstitutional and requires lawyers accused of it to provide nondiscriminatory explanation for juror selection.
lead_paragraph: There appeared to be consensus on the court that prosecutors in 1987 crossed a constitutional line in a capital case against a black man accused of killing a white woman.

headline.main: Supreme Court to Decide if Georgia Went Too Far in Excluding Black Jurors
headline.print_headline: Justices Hear Bias Case on Excluding Black Jurors
